cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: People working on a disabled vehicle:
questions.answerA: Are probably aware of the roadway.
questions.answerB: May be distracted by the repair and not pay attention to the roadway.
questions.answerC: Are exempt from traffic laws.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on a disabled vehicle on the side of the road. They may be focused on the repair and not paying attention to nearby traffic.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of tie-down equipment?
questions.answerB: Straps
questions.answerC: Velcro
questions.explanation: You must use the proper number of tie-downs when securing cargo on a flatbed trailer. Examples of tie-down equipment includes ropes, straps, and chains.

questions.question: Vehicles driving behind a truck:
questions.answerA: May have difficulty seeing objects in front of the truck.
questions.answerB: Often have a great view of the roadway in front of them.
questions.answerC: Do not need to signal.
questions.explanation: Your truck may block the views of drivers behind you, making them unaware of any upcoming hazards that require you to stop. For this reason, it is a good idea to flash your brakes and warn other drivers before slowing or stopping.

questions.question: If you are driving and the ABS light comes on, it means that the ABS:
questions.answerA: Cannot work due to weather conditions.
questions.answerB: Has just been activated.
questions.answerC: Is not working properly.
questions.explanation: ABS malfunction lamps indicate that something in the Anti-Lock Braking System is not working properly.

questions.question: You must have an air brake endorsement:
questions.answerA: To use a vehicle with air brakes.
questions.answerB: To drive any truck with a trailer.
questions.answerC: To transport hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: You must take an air brakes knowledge test to become licensed to operate a vehicle that is equipped with air brakes, including an air over hydraulic braking system.

questions.question: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and figure out what's wrong.
questions.answerC: Run the air conditioner.
questions.explanation: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should stop driving as soon as possible and try to figure out what is wrong. There could be an issue in your vehicle that could lead to engine failure and possibly a fire.

questions.question: Drowsy driving is most common during:
questions.answerB: The early morning.
questions.answerC: The mid-afternoon.
questions.explanation: Drowsy driving is most common during the night because people are naturally prone to be less alert in the hours during which they are normally asleep. If you must drive at night, take every precaution to prevent fatigued driving.

questions.question: You should check and adjust your mirrors:
questions.answerB: While driving.
questions.answerC: After driving.
questions.explanation: Be sure to check your mirrors before beginning a drive. Your posture may change day to day and your mirrors may need to be adjusted.

questions.question: Escape ramps are ramps that can be used:
questions.answerB: To leave the highway and enter a two-lane highway.
questions.answerC: To stop runaway vehicles on steep downhills.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are constructed in areas with steep downgrades to allow a means of safely stopping runaway vehicles. They consist of a long bed of loose, soft material, and sometimes an uphill slope.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.answerB: 50 degrees.
questions.answerC: 75 degrees.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: Lights that indicate that anti-lock brakes are not working are:
questions.answerB: Blue.
questions.answerC: Yellow.
questions.explanation: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lights to indicate issues in the braking system.

questions.question: When checking your mirrors:
questions.answerA: The passenger side mirror should not be used.
questions.answerB: The driver's side mirror should not be used.
questions.answerC: Mirrors on both sides of the vehicle should be used.
questions.explanation: Regularly check mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while driving. It is important to be aware of what is happening behind and to the sides of your vehicle.

questions.question: If approaching a vehicle with a distracted driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Maintain a safe distance from the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Closely follow the vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you see a distracted driver, give them plenty of space and maintain a safe following distance.

questions.question: When you must travel down a hill, when should you switch into a lower gear?
questions.answerA: As you begin to move downward
questions.answerB: As you go downhill and pick up speed
questions.answerC: Before you start going downhill
questions.explanation: You should always slow down and shift into a lower gear before starting down a hill. If you do not begin to drive down a hill at a low enough speed, you risk overusing your brakes, causing them to overheat and fade.

questions.question: If you must back up, it is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Drive as fast as possible to complete the maneuver quickly.
questions.answerB: First walk the line of travel to look for obstacles.
questions.answerC: Use only the passenger side mirror.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, you should exit the cab and check your path for obstacles before beginning the maneuver. Drive as slowly as you can, checking your mirrors on both sides.

questions.question: Most heavy vehicles use the ____ method when changing gears.
questions.answerB: Double shifting
questions.answerC: Triple clutching
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with unsynchronized manual transmissions require double clutching to change gears.

questions.question: When driving at highway speeds, you should watch the road about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: 100 yards
questions.answerC: A quarter mile
questions.explanation: Stay aware of upcoming obstacles and hazards by consistently watching the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. When traveling at highway speeds, this is equivalent to about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: When driving a truck requiring a CDL:
questions.answerA: You do not need to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You must always wear a seat belt.
questions.explanation: You must be properly restrained by a safety belt at all times when driving a commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: When driving under wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that:
questions.answerA: Ice has formed on the road.
questions.answerB: The pavement is dry.
questions.answerC: The spray is caught on the underside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: In wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that ice has formed on the road. Be especially cautious when traveling under wet conditions in freezing weather.

questions.question: If backing a truck:
questions.answerA: You should rely on your mirrors to guide you.
questions.answerB: You should first walk the area to become more familiar with obstacles.
questions.answerC: You should look straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should first walk around your vehicle to look at the path of travel and check for obstacles. Because mirrors have blind spots, you cannot rely exclusively on them. It is recommended to use a helper whenever possible.

questions.question: If you plan to transport hazardous materials, you must pass which endorsement test?
questions.answerB: Hazardous materials
questions.answerC: Passengers
questions.explanation: You must have a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport defined classes of hazardous materials.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), when the vehicle is started:
questions.answerB: The ABS indicator light should turn on, then quickly shut off.
questions.answerC: The steering wheel will not move until the air tanks are full.
questions.explanation: After starting the engine of a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), the indicator light should come on and then turn off. If the light stays on, something is wrong with the ABS.

questions.question: Talking on a hands-free phone while driving:
questions.answerB: Only distracts the driver if the driver is speaking.
questions.answerC: Can be distracting to the driver.
questions.explanation: While speaking on a hands-free phone while driving is less dangerous than speaking on a hand-held phone, it is just as likely to mentally distract a driver. Simply engaging in conversation takes their mental focus away from the task of driving.

questions.question: Traction is important in:
questions.answerB: Properly using turn signals.
questions.answerC: Operating the horn.
questions.explanation: You will not be able to brake or steer your vehicle without adequate traction. Ensure that your tires are in proper working condition before beginning a trip.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Should not be used in cold weather.
questions.answerB: Are helpful to remove water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerC: Are used to move air to the brakes.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually has a certain amount of water and oil in it. This can harm the system if allowed to accumulate. Air tanks have drain valves to aid in removing water and oil from the compressed air.

questions.question: If exiting a bus, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Never make contact with the handrail.
questions.answerB: Maintain contact with the handrail.
questions.answerC: Move quickly.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: ABS brakes:
questions.answerB: Lock up your vehicle's wheels.
questions.answerC: Prevent your vehicle from accelerating when going uphill.
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/left parking maneuver, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place a well-balanced amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Place weight over only the axles.
questions.explanation: A load of cargo must be properly balanced. Placing too much weight over an axle can damage the axle and make it more difficult for you to steer. Placing too little weight over an axle can cause poor traction, also leading to difficult handling.

questions.question: On any upgrade, gravity will:
questions.answerB: Slow your vehicle down.
questions.answerC: Not impact your speed.
questions.explanation: A vehicle will be slowed down by gravity on any uphill grade. You may need to switch to a lower gear to climb a steep grade.

questions.question: Bridges usually:
questions.answerB: Have heaters to prevent them from freezing.
questions.answerC: Freeze before other surfaces.
questions.explanation: Bridges tend to freeze before other parts of the road surface. You should be especially careful on bridges when temperatures are near the freezing point.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerB: Rise slowly.
questions.answerC: Jump quickly.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the coolant temperature should rise gradually to a normal operating range.

questions.question: Reading a text message while driving is:
questions.answerB: Allowed only if you are not pulling a trailer.
questions.answerC: Illegal.
questions.explanation: Sending and reading text messages while driving is both dangerous and illegal.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indicator of when to change gears?
questions.answerB: Road speed (mph)
questions.answerC: The speed of the vehicle next to you
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: A person driving with an open window in cold weather may be:
questions.answerB: A person who is dressed inappropriately.
questions.answerC: A person who likes fresh air.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they have their windows rolled down in cold weather.

questions.question: When slowing down, you should ____ to warn other drivers
questions.answerB: Sound your horn
questions.answerC: Tap your brakes
questions.explanation: Before slowing down, it can be a good idea to lightly tap your brakes. This will cause your brake lights to flash, providing a warning to motorists behind you.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerB: The nuts could be loose.
questions.answerC: The tires should be replaced.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: On a leaf spring:
questions.answerB: Leaves can be missing.
questions.answerC: Leaves should not be broken.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's suspension, verify that leaf springs do not have missing or broken leaves. If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: When driving, being aware of what is happening behind you is:
questions.answerB: Important.
questions.answerC: Distracting.
questions.explanation: When driving, it is important to be aware of what is happening behind and to the sides of your vehicle. Mirror checks and head checks should be a normal part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: Hanging meat:
questions.answerA: Should never be transported by trailer.
questions.answerB: Can be an unstable load.
questions.answerC: Must be approved by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: The tire load for a tire is stated:
questions.answerA: On the side of the tire.
questions.answerB: On the inside of the tire.
questions.answerC: On the inside of the driver’s door.
questions.explanation: The tire load, or the maximum safe weight that a tire can carry at a given pressure, is stated on the side of each tire.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle, rough acceleration is:
questions.answerB: Encouraged at all speeds.
questions.answerC: Discouraged at all speeds.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no more than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement.
questions.explanation: Cargo inside a trailer must be secured appropriately to prevent it from shifting in transit.

questions.question: How can a driver maintain alertness while driving?
questions.answerB: Keep the cab warm
questions.answerC: Eat heavy foods
questions.explanation: Eating heavy foods before driving or keeping the temperature in a cab too high can cause a driver to become drowsy while behind the wheel. Exercising and maintaining a healthy diet will help a driver to stay alert while driving.

questions.question: A driver may have:
questions.answerA: Two licenses: one for automobiles and one for trucks.
questions.answerB: Only one license.
questions.answerC: A license for every state in which they drive.
questions.explanation: A person may not have more than one license. Violation of this law may be punishable by jail time and/or a fine of up to $5,000.

questions.question: If being tailgated, you should:
questions.answerB: Increase the amount of space between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerC: Make quick movements.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, you should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead of you. This reduces the need for you to make sudden changes in speed or direction while making it easier for the tailgater to pass your vehicle.

questions.question: Who is responsible for ensuring cargo is loaded properly?
questions.answerB: The shipper
questions.answerC: The recipient
questions.explanation: A driver is responsible for four things related to transporting cargo. They are responsible for inspecting the cargo, recognizing overloads and poorly balanced weight, ensuring that the cargo is secured without obstructing their view, and ensuring that the cargo is not obstructing access to emergency equipment.

questions.question: Hanging meat as cargo is:
questions.answerA: Illegal to transport in most states.
questions.answerB: Always easy to transport.
questions.answerC: Usually unstable.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: What is a retarder?
questions.answerA: A device that prevents a vehicle from going too fast
questions.answerB: A device that prevents a vehicle from being too loud
questions.answerC: A device that improves a vehicle's gas mileage
questions.explanation: Retarders help to slow vehicles, reducing drivers' need to use brakes.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked vehicles, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Watch for signs of a person exiting a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Flash their headlights.
questions.explanation: You should be cautious when passing parked vehicles. A person may step out of a parked vehicle or out from between parked vehicles without looking for oncoming traffic. A driver may begin moving their vehicle before realizing you are there.

questions.question: You should specifically look out for black ice:
questions.answerB: When the temperature is below freezing and the road looks wet.
questions.answerC: When the temperature is above freezing and there is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. Be alert to black ice any time the temperature is below freezing and the road surface looks wet.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal:
questions.answerA: Is not recommended on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerC: Is optional on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.explanation: Any vehicle with air brakes must be equipped with a low air pressure warning signal.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: If you see taillights ahead while you are driving in fog:
questions.answerA: The lights may not indicate where the road is as the vehicle may have pulled off the roadway.
questions.answerB: You can assume the vehicle ahead is on the road.
questions.answerC: It may be an optical illusion.
questions.explanation: When driving under foggy conditions, lights cannot be taken as a reliable indication of where the road is. The lights may be coming from a vehicle that has pulled off the road.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road:
questions.answerA: A driver should keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.answerB: A driver should turn on the emergency flashers.
questions.answerC: The driver should wave their arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, make sure to use your four-way emergency flashers. This is particularly important at night.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation in your personal car:
questions.answerB: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Law enforcement will tell your employer.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerA: Usually have a low center of gravity.
questions.answerB: Usually have a high center of gravity.
questions.answerC: Are usually not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Driving with dry bulk tanks requires special care because they usually have high centers of gravity. It is also important for drivers to be prepared for the contents to shift in transit.

questions.question: Which of the following does not indicate bad brakes?
questions.answerB: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.answerC: Very thin shoes
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should check for cracked drums; shoes or pads covered in oil, grease, or brake fluid; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors before a trip:
questions.answerA: No part of your vehicle should be visible in any mirror.
questions.answerB: Part of your vehicle should be visible in the mirrors.
questions.answerC: More than half of each mirror should show the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When properly adjusted, your mirrors should each display some part of your vehicle. Being able to see your own vehicle in your mirrors will give you a point of reference when judging the positions of other objects.

questions.question: A fatigued driver:
questions.answerB: Is usually more conscientious than a typical driver.
questions.answerC: May be slower to make critical decisions than a typical driver.
questions.explanation: Fatigued drivers are slower to see or react to hazards than drivers who are not fatigued. Drivers are impaired in their ability to make critical decisions when they are driving drowsy.

questions.question: Header boards:
questions.answerB: Protect the driver from being hit by cargo.
questions.answerC: Have no benefits.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep grade, you switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: When you have already started the grade.
questions.answerC: As far down the grade as possible.
questions.explanation: You should shift your vehicle's transmission into a low gear before staring a downhill grade. Be prepared for gravity to increase your vehicle's speed when traveling downhill.

questions.question: An over-length load requires:
questions.answerB: A convoy to halt all traffic.
questions.answerC: A person to walk alongside the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Over-length, over-width, and/or overweight loads may require special permits to be transported. In some cases, it may be necessary for the load to be accompanied by a pilot vehicle with warning signs and flashing lights or a police escort.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance of driving to:
questions.answerA: Recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.answerC: Polish the tire.
questions.explanation: Once you have begun to drive after a tire has been changed, you should stop after a short distance to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: Regrooved tires:
questions.answerA: Should not be used on any vehicle.
questions.answerB: Should not be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: Should not be used on trucks hauling gravel.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, it is important to maintain ____ with your vehicle at all times.
questions.answerB: Four points of contact
questions.answerC: Two points of contact
questions.explanation: As you exit your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: As the driver of a truck carrying a load, you are responsible for all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Recognizing poorly balanced weight.
questions.answerC: Knowing the phone numbers of all fire departments along your intended route of travel.
questions.explanation: It is the driver's responsibility to inspect their cargo; recognize overloading or poorly balanced weight; know that the cargo is properly secured and does not obscure the driver's view; and know that the cargo does not restrict access to emergency equipment. The driver is responsible for their cargo even if they were not the one who initially loaded and secured the cargo.

questions.question: Dual tires should:
questions.answerA: Not both be in contact with the road surface.
questions.answerB: Not touch one another.
questions.answerC: Be different sizes from one another.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should verify that your dual tires do not come into contact with one another, or with any other part of the vehicle.

questions.question: When carrying a sealed load, a driver:
questions.answerA: Should unseal the load to ensure safety.
questions.answerB: Should ensure the weight does not exceed weight limits.
questions.answerC: Must go through the container before driving.
questions.explanation: Though a driver cannot inspect a sealed load, they should still ensure that the load does not exceed applicable weight limits.

questions.question: Who is responsible for cargo that has been loaded onto a truck?
questions.answerA: The person who loaded the truck
questions.answerB: The supervisor of the company
questions.answerC: The truck driver
questions.explanation: Even if they did not load or secure the cargo themselves, the driver of a vehicle is responsible for inspecting the cargo and ensuring that it is properly secured.

questions.question: If you have more than one license:
questions.answerB: You should not tell anyone.
questions.answerC: You may get caught through the states' shared computer network.
questions.explanation: All states share driver information through a computerized database in order to prevent the issuance of multiple licenses to a single person. It is prohibited for a person to have more than one driver license.

questions.question: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Too much air pressure in your tires.
questions.answerB: Too little air pressure in your tires.
questions.answerC: A consistent name brand across all of your tires.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should verify that the air pressure is neither too low nor too high in any of your tires.

questions.question: When checking tires, which of the following should not cause concern?
questions.answerB: Tread of at least 4/32 of an inch on front tires
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.explanation: When checking the tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, make sure the tires have sufficient tread. There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread in every major groove of the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on the other tires. Tires should not be mismatched in size and radial and bias-ply tires should not be used together.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Is common if a vehicle is warmed up.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve gas mileage.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so the vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: Friction in an S-cam brake is caused when the brake shoes and linings:
questions.answerA: Press against the outside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Press against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerC: Push against each other.
questions.explanation: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings push against the inside of the drum. The friction in the drums will slow and stop the vehicle.

questions.question: Vehicles driving behind a truck:
questions.answerA: May have difficulty seeing objects in front of the truck.
questions.answerB: Often have a great view of the roadway in front of them.
questions.answerC: Do not need to signal.
questions.explanation: Your truck may block the views of drivers behind you, making them unaware of any upcoming hazards that require you to stop. For this reason, it is a good idea to flash your brakes and warn other drivers before slowing or stopping.

questions.question: A second conviction of operating a CMV with a blood alcohol content (BAC) of 0.04 percent or more will result in:
questions.answerA: The loss of your CDL for one year.
questions.answerB: The loss of your CDL for five years.
questions.answerC: The loss of your CDL for life.
questions.explanation: A first conviction of operating a CMV with a blood alcohol content (BAC) of 0.04 percent or higher will result in the loss of your CDL for one year. A second conviction of operating a CMV with a minimum BAC of 0.04 percent will result in the loss of your CDL for life.

questions.question: What is a Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR)?
questions.answerA: The value stated by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle
questions.answerB: The rating of a tire
questions.answerC: The rating of a combination vehicle per axle
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle.

questions.question: Slow down and be extra careful:
questions.answerB: When driving on dry pavement.
questions.answerC: When approaching a work zone.
questions.explanation: Slow down and be especially careful when driving in and around work zones, in places where the pavement drops off sharply at the edge of the road, when foreign objects are present on the road, and on freeway on- and off-ramps.

questions.question: The use of a hand-held mobile device while driving is:
questions.answerB: Acceptable if weather conditions are clear.
questions.answerC: Permitted if use is work-related.
questions.explanation: Using a hand-held mobile telephone while operating a CMV is both illegal and dangerous.

questions.question: Before attempting to put out an engine fire:
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The accelerator should be depressed to use up the remaining fuel.
questions.explanation: If you experience an engine fire, you should turn off the engine as soon as safely possible. Avoid opening the vehicle's hood when extinguishing the fire.

questions.question: When traveling long distances, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive as fast as possible.
questions.answerC: Drive through the night.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should take a break after every 100 miles or two hours of driving. Driving through the night, or during any other time when you would normally be asleep, raises the danger of fatigue.

questions.question: Blocking cargo:
questions.answerB: Should be done to prevent shifting of cargo.
questions.answerC: Should only be done with welded material.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be blocked to prevent it from sliding around in transit. The shifting of weight in transit can make steering and handling difficult for the driver.

questions.question: You should ____ if the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving.
questions.answerA: Stop where you are and park
questions.answerB: Exit the roadway as soon as safely possible
questions.answerC: Continue driving normally
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: Drivers may not operate a CMV with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerB: 0.04 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.08 percent.
questions.explanation: You will lose your CDL for at least one year if you are found to be operating with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.04 percent or higher. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a CMV while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Causing a fatality through negligent operation of a CMV will result in the loss of your CDL for at least:
questions.answerB: Six months.
questions.answerC: One year.
questions.explanation: A first conviction of causing a fatality through negligent operation of a CMV will result in the loss of your CDL for at least one year.

questions.question: To make your vehicle more visible during the day, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Use your clearance lights.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used for best visibility, even during the day. Using high beam headlights around other drivers can be dangerous.

questions.question: Cargo should be covered:
questions.answerB: To hide the materials.
questions.answerC: To make it more difficult to steal.
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: What is road rage?
questions.answerA: Operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others
questions.answerB: Operating a motor vehicle that is deemed unsafe
questions.answerC: Operating a motor vehicle that has not been inspected
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is defined as operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner. Road rage is defined as operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others, or the intent of physically assaulting another driver or their vehicle.

questions.question: If an air compressor is belt-driven, the belt should be routinely checked to ensure that it is:
questions.answerB: Properly tightened.
questions.answerC: Cracked.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. Check the tightness of the belt and verify that it is in good condition.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.answerB: Pushing down quickly.
questions.answerC: Pulling up gradually.
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: Why are multi-speed axles and auxiliary transmissions used?
questions.answerA: To make a vehicle operate more smoothly
questions.answerB: To provide extra gears
questions.answerC: To improve a vehicle's gas mileage
questions.explanation: On many vehicles, multi-speed rear axles and auxiliary transmissions are used to provide extra gears.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you have a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: When mirrors are properly adjusted:
questions.answerA: No part of the vehicle should be visible in the mirrors.
questions.answerB: A part of the vehicle should be visible in the mirrors.
questions.answerC: More than half of each mirror should show the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A properly adjusted mirror will show some portion of the vehicle. This will provide a point of reference to help the driver judge the distance of other objects to the vehicle.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving skills test:
questions.answerA: You do not have to take the test with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.
questions.answerB: You must take the test with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.
questions.answerC: It does not matter which type of vehicle you use to take the test.
questions.explanation: CDL skills tests, including the on-road test, must be taken with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.

questions.question: Emergency equipment in a vehicle is:
questions.answerA: Only required for vehicles that are transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Only required during interstate travel.
questions.answerC: Required.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should check for emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If driving through flowing water or a large puddle, you should:
questions.answerB: Gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Try to stop in the water.
questions.explanation: It is best to avoid driving through large puddles or moving water. If there is no way to avoid driving through water, you should slow down, shift into a low gear, and gently apply the brakes. Pressing linings against the brake drums or discs will keep water, mud, silt, and sand from getting inside the brake mechanisms.

questions.question: Why should you regularly drain the air tanks?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water and the water collects in the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in pressure
questions.explanation: Compressed air usually contains a certain amount of moisture and compressor oil, which can build up in the air storage tanks and damage the brake system. The tanks should be drained to clean out these accumulations. On a tank with a manual drain valve, draining should be performed at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: How can a driver maintain alertness while driving?
questions.answerB: Keep the cab warm
questions.answerC: Eat heavy foods
questions.explanation: Eating heavy foods before driving or keeping the temperature in a cab too high can cause a driver to become drowsy while behind the wheel. Exercising and maintaining a healthy diet will help a driver to stay alert while driving.

questions.question: When approaching a construction worker who is near the road, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder.
questions.explanation: Always drive with caution through work zones. You should make a particular point of reducing your speed when workers are on or near the roadway.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load on a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts should be:
questions.answerB: Checked for tightness.
questions.answerC: Scrubbed clean.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check all belts for tightness and excessive wear. You should learn how much "give" is appropriate for each belt.

questions.question: Do not base your decision to shift gears on:
questions.answerB: The speed of the road (mph).
questions.answerC: The actions of the vehicle next to you.
questions.explanation: One way to know when it is time to shift gears is to learn your vehicle's operating rpm range. You should shift up when your engine reaches the top of that range. You can also learn which speeds each gear is good for and shift up based on your speedometer.

questions.question: If you must back up, it is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Drive as fast as possible to complete the maneuver quickly.
questions.answerB: First walk the line of travel to look for obstacles.
questions.answerC: Use only the passenger side mirror.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, you should exit the cab and check your path for obstacles before beginning the maneuver. Drive as slowly as you can, checking your mirrors on both sides.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place an appropriate amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with how the cargo's weight is distributed.
questions.explanation: When loading cargo, it is important that the weight placed on each axle is neither too little nor too much. Inappropriate loading can interfere with steering, create inadequate wheel traction, or damage the axles.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, a look is when:
questions.answerA: A driver checks the gauges on their instrument panel.
questions.answerB: A driver checks their blind spots.
questions.answerC: A driver walks to the back of their vehicle to check its position.
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: When approaching a vehicle for a pre-trip inspection, a driver should look under the vehicle:
questions.answerA: To see if the vehicle is on an incline.
questions.answerB: To see if there are any fresh fluids on the ground.
questions.answerC: To see if the vehicle is in a parking spot.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle before an inspection, make note of its general condition and ensure that it is not damaged or leaning. Look under the vehicle for fresh leaks of oil, grease, or fuel. Check around the vehicle for hazards to movement, such as people, other vehicles, or low-hanging wires or tree limbs.

questions.question: The Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) does not need to include which of the following?
questions.answerB: Vehicle Identification Number
questions.answerC: Number of meals eaten by the driver
questions.explanation: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include information about the distance traveled by a vehicle and the amount of fuel purchased. The required distance information includes the origin and destination points of the trip and the Vehicle Identification Number.

questions.question: Air brakes use ____ to function.
questions.answerB: Liquid nitrogen
questions.answerC: Carbon dioxide
questions.explanation: The brakes in an air brake system use compressed air to function properly.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tank drains are used to remove water and compressor oil from the air tanks. When operating a drain, be sure to drain the tank completely.

questions.question: An example of required emergency equipment is:
questions.answerB: A loud horn.
questions.answerC: A battery-operated flashlight.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: What does blocking cargo do?
questions.answerA: Holds the cargo in a large box
questions.answerB: Prevents cargo from sliding in transit
questions.answerC: Prevent others from buying the cargo
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit.

questions.question: Which of the following determines your blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerB: How frequently you drink
questions.answerC: The temperature of the drink
questions.explanation: The main factors that determine a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC) are how much alcohol has been consumed, how quickly it was consumed, and the person's body weight.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person who should concern motorists?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to a passenger in their vehicle
questions.answerB: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.answerC: A construction worker on the side of the road
questions.explanation: You should be cautious when you are near people who are not paying attention to the road. Drivers and pedestrians who are talking to someone may be distracted by the conversation and not fully paying attention to the road. Workers on or near the road may not be paying attention to traffic because they are focused on their work, and can themselves also be a distraction to drivers.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: You should not use your mirrors.
questions.answerB: You should use your mirrors.
questions.answerC: You should not use your turn signals.
questions.explanation: Always use your turn signals and check your mirrors when changing lanes.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be applied.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should be applied.
questions.answerC: Brakes should not be applied if the vehicle is left out of gear.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should be used whenever you park. If necessary, chock your wheels.

questions.question: Bridges usually:
questions.answerB: Have heaters to prevent them from freezing.
questions.answerC: Freeze before other surfaces.
questions.explanation: Bridges tend to freeze before other parts of the road surface. You should be especially careful on bridges when temperatures are near the freezing point.

questions.question: Dual tires should:
questions.answerA: Always come into contact with one another.
questions.answerB: Come into contact with one another fairly regularly.
questions.answerC: Not come into contact with one another.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should verify that your dual tires do not come into contact with one another, or with any other part of the vehicle.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked vehicles, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Watch for signs of a person exiting a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Flash their headlights.
questions.explanation: You should be cautious when passing parked vehicles. A person may step out of a parked vehicle or out from between parked vehicles without looking for oncoming traffic. A driver may begin moving their vehicle before realizing you are there.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Explain why you must check the items you are checking.
questions.answerB: Change the coolant.
questions.answerC: Replace a headlight.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: While still below the legal limit, a driver operating a CMV with a detectable amount of alcohol in their system will:
questions.answerA: Result in an out-of-service order for two hours.
questions.answerB: Result in an out-of-service order for 10 hours.
questions.answerC: Result in an out-of-service order for 24 hours.
questions.explanation: If you are found to have any detectable amount of alcohol in your system while operating a CMV but your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is still below the legal limit of 0.04 percent, you will be put out-of-service for 24 hours. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection should include:
questions.answerA: A check of the engine oil level.
questions.answerB: Removing coolant.
questions.answerC: Washing the tire rims.
questions.explanation: When examining the engine compartment during a pre-trip inspection, you should check the engine oil level, the radiator coolant level, and the condition of the hoses.

questions.question: Shaded areas of a road:
questions.answerB: Are usually blocked from all moisture, so they cannot freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice has melted on other areas of the road.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight and warm up more slowly, shaded areas will remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerA: Pressed down quickly with both feet.
questions.answerB: Pressed down gradually.
questions.answerC: Lifted up quickly.
questions.explanation: When braking, push the pedal down gradually to ensure that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerB: Take special care to be driven.
questions.answerC: Are usually not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care to be driven, both because they have high centers of gravity and because the weight of the load can shift in transit.

questions.question: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and figure out what's wrong.
questions.answerC: Run the air conditioner.
questions.explanation: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should stop driving as soon as possible and try to figure out what is wrong. There could be an issue in your vehicle that could lead to engine failure and possibly a fire.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors before a trip:
questions.answerA: No part of your vehicle should be visible in any mirror.
questions.answerB: Part of your vehicle should be visible in the mirrors.
questions.answerC: More than half of each mirror should show the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When properly adjusted, your mirrors should each display some part of your vehicle. Being able to see your own vehicle in your mirrors will give you a point of reference when judging the positions of other objects.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving skills test:
questions.answerA: You do not have to take the test with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.
questions.answerB: You must take the test with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.
questions.answerC: It does not matter which type of vehicle you use to take the test.
questions.explanation: CDL skills tests, including the on-road test, must be taken with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.

questions.question: Driving with a cargo of hanging meat in a trailer:
questions.answerA: Is discouraged during the summer months.
questions.answerB: Can be problematic because animals are attracted to the smell of the meat.
questions.answerC: Is challenging because the load has a high center of gravity.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.answerB: Ammonia
questions.answerC: Liquid cleaners
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes.

questions.question: If driving on a surface with poor traction, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is always good to accelerate slowly.
questions.answerB: To keep from losing control of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: So that they do not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: To avoid a loss of control, you should accelerate slowly when driving in poor-traction conditions, such as rain or snow.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate especially slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is always good to accelerate slowly.
questions.answerB: To keep from losing control of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: To keep from accelerating faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: You should accelerate very gradually when driving under slippery conditions. Using too much power in such conditions may cause you to lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Is caused only by physical distractions.
questions.answerB: Will be increased by pre-programming radio stations.
questions.answerC: Can be prevented by avoiding conversation with others.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used if carrying a light load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are never safe to use.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.answerB: 150 miles.
questions.answerC: 500 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: The vehicle should be placed in a low gear and the driver should use engine braking.
questions.answerC: The driver should continually downshift instead of using the brakes.
questions.explanation: On long and/or steep downgrades, you should primarily use engine braking to control the speed of your vehicle. Use your brakes only as a supplement to this effect.

questions.question: Foundation brakes are used:
questions.answerA: Only on the front wheels of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Only on the rear wheels of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: On each wheel of a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Foundation brakes are used on each wheel of a CMV. The most common type of foundation brake is the s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: Mirrors should be:
questions.answerB: Checked frequently.
questions.answerC: Checked only if there is a reason to suspect a problem.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should regularly check your mirrors, both to be aware of traffic and to check for problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.answerB: 50 degrees.
questions.answerC: 75 degrees.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerB: Tires are not made to drive in wet weather.
questions.answerC: The water yet hasn't absorbed the dirt and grease.
questions.explanation: Roads are often especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Rainwater forms a slick film when mixed with oil and grease on the road surface that has not yet washed away.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation in your personal car:
questions.answerB: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Law enforcement will tell your employer.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: A fatigued driver:
questions.answerB: Is usually more conscientious than a typical driver.
questions.answerC: May be slower to make critical decisions than a typical driver.
questions.explanation: Fatigued drivers are slower to see or react to hazards than drivers who are not fatigued. Drivers are impaired in their ability to make critical decisions when they are driving drowsy.

questions.question: A steering wheel should be:
questions.answerA: Held with one hand while the other hand rests.
questions.answerB: Held with both hands to ensure an adequate grip.
questions.answerC: Released if the vehicle is approaching a bump.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with each hand on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: Header boards:
questions.answerB: Protect the driver from being hit by cargo.
questions.answerC: Protect the driver's head when entering the cab of a truck.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: You may:
questions.answerA: Have more than one license if one is for business purposes.
questions.answerB: Have more than one license if they are issued by different states.
questions.answerC: Not have more than one license.
questions.explanation: A person cannot have more than one driver license at a time. States share information through a computer database to ensure that no person has more than one license. Violation of this law could result in fines or jail time.

questions.question: A ____ allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes.
questions.answerB: Trailer air supply control
questions.answerC: Relay valve
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indicator of when to change gears?
questions.answerB: Road speed (mph)
questions.answerC: The speed of the vehicle next to you
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: Blocking is used to:
questions.answerA: Keep cargo in a large box.
questions.answerB: Prevent cargo from sliding in a trailer.
questions.answerC: Prevent cargo from falling out of a trailer.
questions.explanation: Blocking may be used on all sides of a piece of cargo to keep it from sliding while the vehicle is in motion.

questions.question: If you are confronted with an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to stay in their way.
questions.answerC: Ignore any hand gestures.
questions.explanation: The best thing to do when confronted with an aggressive driver is to get out of their way, if possible. Avoid making eye contact, which could further provoke the driver. Ignore any hand gestures made by the driver.

questions.question: Aggressive driving is:
questions.answerA: Operating a vehicle in a selfish or pushy manner.
questions.answerB: Operating a vehicle with a strong regard for other motorists’ safety.
questions.answerC: Operating a vehicle in the left lane.
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is the act of operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner and without regard for the rights or safety of other road users.

questions.question: If planning to stop on the road to unload cargo, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop suddenly, since you are already on the road.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers by tapping your brakes.
questions.answerC: Wave your arm out the window to get the attention of other drivers.
questions.explanation: You should tap your brakes and flash your brake lights to warn other drivers any time you plan to slow or stop where other drivers may not expect you to do so. Use this technique when stopping on the road to unload cargo or passengers.

questions.question: Your CDL will be revoked if:
questions.answerA: You want to add an endorsement.
questions.answerB: Your privilege to operate your personal vehicle is revoked.
questions.answerC: You have not paid a toll.
questions.explanation: If your privilege to operate your personal vehicle is revoked, canceled, or suspended due to moving traffic violations, you will also lose your CDL. This does not apply if your license is revoked due to parking violations.

questions.question: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and figure out what's wrong.
questions.answerC: Run the air conditioner.
questions.explanation: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should stop driving as soon as possible and try to figure out what is wrong. There could be an issue in your vehicle that could lead to engine failure and possibly a fire.

questions.question: Some air brake systems introduce alcohol into the system to:
questions.answerA: Make the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevent ice from forming in the brake system.
questions.answerC: Prevent people from breathing the air from the system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. An evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help inhibit the formation of ice in cold weather.

questions.question: Blocking is used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent cargo from being loaded too high.
questions.answerC: Prevent cargo from being unloaded too quickly.
questions.explanation: Blocking is used in the front, in the back, and/or on the sides of a piece of cargo to keep it from sliding while the vehicle is in motion.

questions.question: When asked to make a lane change during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Make the change as soon as the examiner asks, without looking.
questions.answerB: Use your turn signal and change lanes when safe.
questions.answerC: Make the lane change as quickly as possible, even if that means cutting off another driver.
questions.explanation: You will be asked to change lanes during the on-road driving test. When the examiner asks you to do this, you should make the necessary traffic checks and use the proper signals before changing lanes.

questions.question: Without the proper amount of oil in its engine:
questions.answerA: A vehicle will have difficulty stopping.
questions.answerB: A vehicle will make quick, jerking movements while being driven.
questions.answerC: The engine may be quickly damaged.
questions.explanation: It is essential that a vehicle's engine have adequate oil pressure. An engine can be destroyed rapidly if it is run without oil.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerB: There is no trailer.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with one or more trailers, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the trailers are straight. Mirror adjustment should be checked before the start of every trip.

questions.question: Why should the steps of a pre-trip inspection be done in the same order each time?
questions.answerA: Because you will be less likely to forget to check something
questions.answerB: Because it will be faster
questions.answerC: Because it is required by law
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: When driving at highway speeds, you should watch the road about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: 100 yards
questions.answerC: A quarter mile
questions.explanation: Stay aware of upcoming obstacles and hazards by consistently watching the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. When traveling at highway speeds, this is equivalent to about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: Water that has collected on a roadway can cause:
questions.answerB: Acceleration.
questions.answerC: Stopping.
questions.explanation: The risk of hydroplaning begins when water has collected on the surface of a road.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the truck from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.answerC: Check the engine oil level.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: When checking tires, which of the following should not cause concern?
questions.answerB: Tread of at least 4/32 of an inch on front tires
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.explanation: When checking the tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, make sure the tires have sufficient tread. There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread in every major groove of the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on the other tires. Tires should not be mismatched in size and radial and bias-ply tires should not be used together.

questions.question: While driving, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Not be concerned with what is happening on the sides of their vehicle.
questions.answerB: Be concerned with what is happening on all sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with what is happening behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Scan the road ahead and make regular checks of the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while you are driving.

questions.question: A jogger wearing a stereo headset:
questions.answerA: Is probably aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerB: May not be aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerC: Can hear the sounds of traffic.
questions.explanation: Be careful around pedestrians, joggers, and cyclists who are wearing headphones. They may be unable to hear your vehicle approaching and may do dangerous things because they do not know you are there.

questions.question: Why do large vehicles use air brakes?
questions.answerA: Other brake systems squeak too loudly.
questions.answerB: Air brakes are very effective systems.
questions.answerC: Other braking systems are hard to come by.
questions.explanation: If used and maintained properly, air brakes are a safe and effective way to stop large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: By beginning a left turn before reaching the center of an intersection, you:
questions.answerA: Will likely complete the turn satisfactorily.
questions.answerB: May hit other vehicles with the left side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Can expect other drivers to move their vehicles to accommodate your turn.
questions.explanation: When planning to turn left at an intersection, make sure you have reached the center of the intersection before beginning the turn. If you turn too soon, off-tracking may cause the left side of your vehicle to hit another vehicle.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.answerC: Not safe to be used.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: Shortly after a tire has been changed, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop to make sure the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.answerB: Repair the brakes.
questions.answerC: Deflate the tire to 10 psi.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop a short while later to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: The faster you drive:
questions.answerA: The shorter your stopping distance will be.
questions.answerB: The longer your stopping distance will be.
questions.answerC: The easier it will be to stop your vehicle.
questions.explanation: The faster you are driving, the longer your stopping distance will become. Brake accordingly.

questions.question: If there is a fire in your vehicle and you are not sure how to extinguish it, you should:
questions.answerB: Try douse the flames with water.
questions.answerC: Move away from the flames and wait for the firefighters.
questions.explanation: If you are not sure which method to use when putting out a fire, do not attempt to extinguish the fire on your own. Instead, wait for firefighters to arrive and let them handle it. This is especially true if you are experiencing a hazardous materials fire.

questions.question: If making a tight turn, the operator of a CMV should:
questions.answerA: Be able to drive as fast as the driver of a car.
questions.answerB: Not be concerned about speed, but focus on the road.
questions.answerC: Warn drivers behind by braking early and slowing gradually.
questions.explanation: Drivers behind you may not anticipate how slowly your CMV must travel to safely make a right turn. You can help warn them in advance by braking early and slowing gradually.

questions.question: A ____ allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes.
questions.answerB: Trailer air supply control
questions.answerC: Relay valve
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: To determine if a vehicle can handle a load, you must know:
questions.answerB: The tire rating for the front tires only.
questions.answerC: The tire rating for the rear tires only.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to make sure their vehicle is not overloaded. They must be aware of legal weight limits and the maximum weight that their vehicle is rated to carry, including the weight capacity rating of the suspension system.

questions.question: What is the Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR)?
questions.answerA: The weight stated by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle
questions.answerB: The maximum weight that can be pulled by a vehicle
questions.answerC: The minimum weight that can be hauled by a vehicle
questions.explanation: A Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle.

questions.question: When driving a 50-foot truck at 50 mph, your minimum following distance should be:
questions.answerB: Five seconds.
questions.answerC: Six seconds.
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. When traveling at higher speeds, follow the same formula, then add one additional second to your following distance.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerB: The gas pedal is loose.
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: Alcohol is removed from the body:
questions.answerB: At a fixed rate.
questions.answerC: More quickly if the person stays awake.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, tricks like drinking coffee or taking a cold shower will not speed up the process. The only way to become sober is to allow your body the time it needs to remove the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, the heaviest cargo should be placed:
questions.answerA: On top of the lightest parts of the cargo.
questions.answerB: Under the lightest parts of the cargo.
questions.answerC: At the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is important that vehicles are not top-heavy, if at all possible. A top-heavy vehicle is at an increased risk of rollover. Place the heaviest pieces of cargo underneath lighter pieces of cargo.

questions.question: When driving on a wet road, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.answerB: About one-third.
questions.answerC: About one-quarter.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by about one-third when driving on a wet road.

questions.question: Alcohol begins to affect the body:
questions.answerB: After several drinks have been consumed.
questions.answerC: At the legal limit.
questions.explanation: Alcohol consumption impairs muscle coordination, reaction time, depth perception, vision, judgement, and inhibition. For some people, signs of impairment may begin with the first drink of alcohol. It is safest to not operate any motor vehicle after consuming alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: In poor weather, many drivers:
questions.answerA: Like to drive in front of trucks.
questions.answerB: Like to drive to the sides of trucks.
questions.answerC: Like to follow trucks.
questions.explanation: In bad weather, many automobile drivers will follow large trucks too closely, particularly if visibility is poor.

questions.question: Header boards:
questions.answerB: Protect the driver from being hit by cargo.
questions.answerC: Protect the driver's head when entering the cab of a truck.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: An air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of the air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: What can happen if the exhaust system is not working properly?
questions.answerA: Poisonous fumes may enter the cab.
questions.answerB: Fumes may exit the rear of the muffler system.
questions.answerC: Proper steering may be impossible.
questions.explanation: Leaks in an exhaust system are extremely dangerous because they may allow toxic fumes into the cab or sleeper berth, endangering drivers and passengers.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, if one air system is very low on pressure:
questions.answerA: None of the brakes will work at all.
questions.answerB: Either the front or rear brakes will not be fully operable.
questions.answerC: There is usually no noticeable effect.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, either the front or rear brakes will not be fully operable if one of the air systems gets too low on pressure. If the air pressure in either tank gets too low while you are driving, you should exit the road and park as soon as possible.

questions.question: What is often found in compressed air?
questions.answerB: Cardboard
questions.answerC: Brake fluid
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, you should:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place a well-balanced amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with how the weight is distributed.
