questions.explanation: A load of cargo must be properly balanced. Placing too much weight over an axle can damage the axle and make it more difficult for you to steer. Placing too little weight over an axle can cause poor traction, also leading to difficult handling.

questions.question: Escape ramps are ramps that can be used:
questions.answerB: To leave the highway and enter a two-lane highway.
questions.answerC: To stop runaway vehicles on steep downhills.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are constructed in areas with steep downgrades to allow a means of safely stopping runaway vehicles. They consist of a long bed of loose, soft material, and sometimes an uphill slope.

questions.question: To avoid a crash:
questions.answerA: Braking is always the best option.
questions.answerB: Swerving may be more effective than braking.
questions.answerC: Drivers should leave 100 yards of distance between their vehicle and the next.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the safest response to a hazard on the road. You can almost always turn to avoid an obstacle faster than you can stop.

questions.question: Skids caused by over-acceleration can usually be resolved by:
questions.answerA: Removing your foot from the accelerator.
questions.answerB: Braking.
questions.answerC: Swerving to the right.
questions.explanation: A skid caused by over-acceleration can be resolved simply by removing your foot from the accelerator. Skids of this nature happen most frequently on surfaces covered in snow or ice.

questions.question: If using spring brakes when hauling a heavy load, a complete stop will:
questions.answerB: Take a long time.
questions.answerC: Take a short amount of time.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes do not work on all axles. If your vehicle's spring brakes activate due to low pressure in an air brake system, your vehicle will need a longer distance to stop than usual, especially if you are carrying a heavy load.

questions.question: If you are taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take a different route.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, if your route does not include a railroad crossing, the examiner may ask you to explain and demonstrate the necessary procedures at a simulated location.

questions.question: Your horn should be used to:
questions.answerA: Tell other drivers that you are angry.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers that you are near.
questions.answerC: Frighten other drivers.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's horn is a tool to warn others of your presence. Because the horn may create danger by startling other drivers, you should use it only if necessary.

questions.question: Driving at night is usually:
questions.answerA: More difficult than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Simpler than driving during the day.
questions.answerC: Discouraged.
questions.explanation: There are several reasons why driving at night is more difficult than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued drivers on the road.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should:
questions.answerB: Not have excessive wear.
questions.answerC: Be greasy.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: When completing a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: When should a driver sign a vehicle inspection report?
questions.answerB: If noted defects are repaired
questions.answerC: After each fueling
questions.explanation: You must sign a vehicle inspection report only if defects were noted and either certified to have been repaired or certified as not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: When checking windshield wiper blades, they should be:
questions.answerB: Secure.
questions.answerC: Brittle.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check the wiper blades for damage, stiff rubber, and proper securement. Clean the blades if they are dirty.

questions.question: ____ is an example of required emergency equipment.
questions.answerB: A loud horn
questions.answerC: A battery-operated flashlight
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: What tells you how much pressure is in your vehicle's air tanks?
questions.answerB: The ABS malfunction lamp
questions.answerC: The tractor protection valve
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Get upset.
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate especially slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is always good to accelerate slowly.
questions.answerB: To keep from losing control of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: To keep from accelerating faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: You should accelerate very gradually when driving under slippery conditions. Using too much power in such conditions may cause you to lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, the heaviest cargo should be placed:
questions.answerA: On top of the lightest parts of the cargo.
questions.answerB: Under the lightest parts of the cargo.
questions.answerC: At the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is important that vehicles are not top-heavy, if at all possible. A top-heavy vehicle is at an increased risk of rollover. Place the heaviest pieces of cargo underneath lighter pieces of cargo.

questions.question: ABS allows a driver to:
questions.answerB: Maintain control of their vehicle while braking.
questions.answerC: See farther ahead of their vehicle.
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to help prevent wheel lockup and help a driver maintain control of their vehicle when braking on a slippery surface.

questions.question: The tire load:
questions.answerA: Can be exceeded in cooler conditions.
questions.answerB: Is the maximum safe weight a tire can carry at a given pressure.
questions.answerC: Must be written in the shipping papers.
questions.explanation: Tire load is the maximum weight a tire can safely carry at a given pressure. This rating is stated on the side of each tire.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher to put out a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay as far away as possible from the flames.
questions.answerB: Aim at the flames.
questions.answerC: Use any extinguisher on every type of fire.
questions.explanation: Stay as far away from a fire as possible and aim your fire extinguisher at the source or base of the fire, not at the flames. It may be appropriate to extinguish certain fires with water. If you are unsure of how to treat a specific fire, you should wait for  trained firefighters to arrive.

questions.question: Where is the overhead inside rearview mirror located?
questions.answerA: Above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus
questions.answerB: Above the door across from the driver
questions.answerC: Above the emergency door in the rear
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror of a school bus should be mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side of the vehicle. It should be used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: When approaching a drawbridge controlled by a green traffic light:
questions.answerB: You may proceed without stopping.
questions.answerC: You must wait for the light to change from green to yellow.
questions.explanation: If a drawbridge is controlled by a traffic signal that is displaying a green light, a bus does not need to stop before crossing the bridge. However, a bus driver should always slow down before crossing a drawbridge to make sure that it is safe to proceed.

questions.question: What does blocking cargo do?
questions.answerA: Holds the cargo in a large box
questions.answerB: Prevents cargo from sliding in transit
questions.answerC: Prevent others from buying the cargo
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit.

questions.question: In very hot weather, tires should be checked regularly because:
questions.answerB: Air pressure may increase with the temperature.
questions.answerC: The tread wears down more quickly than in cooler weather.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases with temperature, you should pay special attention to the tire mounting and pressure when traveling in hot weather.

questions.question: To make it easier to leave a parked position, you should park:
questions.answerA: In a way that allows you to back up when exiting.
questions.answerB: In a way that allows you to pull forward when exiting.
questions.answerC: Only on the side of roadways, not in parking lots.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible. When parking, look to park in a space that will allow you to pull forward when exiting.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerB: Rise slowly.
questions.answerC: Jump quickly.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the coolant temperature should rise gradually to a normal operating range.

questions.question: Emergency equipment in a vehicle is:
questions.answerA: Only required for vehicles that are transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Only required during interstate travel.
questions.answerC: Required.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should check for emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Your horn should be used to:
questions.answerA: Tell other drivers that you are angry.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers that you are near.
questions.answerC: Frighten other drivers.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's horn is a tool to warn others of your presence. Because the horn may create danger by startling other drivers, you should use it only if necessary.

questions.question: To determine if a vehicle can handle a load, you should:
questions.answerB: Know the tire rating for the front tires only.
questions.answerC: Start driving and see if the vehicle is handling well.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to make sure their vehicle is not overloaded. They must be aware of legal weight limits and the maximum weight that their vehicle is rated to carry, including the weight capacity rating of the suspension system.

questions.question: Unsafely reaching for a phone is:
questions.answerA: Acceptable if you are driving without a passenger.
questions.answerB: Acceptable if you plan to use a hands-free feature.
questions.answerC: Unacceptable even if you plan to use a hands-free feature.
questions.explanation: If you must use a mobile phone while driving, it must be in close proximity to you and easily reachable while you are securely fastened into your seat. It is dangerous and non-compliant to unsafely reach for a mobile phone, even if you plan to use a hands-free feature when speaking on the phone.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.answerB: Outside air
questions.answerC: Non-compressed air
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to cover cargo?
questions.answerA: To protect people from spilled cargo
questions.answerB: To protect the cargo from weather
questions.answerC: To keep the cargo a secret
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: If other vehicles are having a difficult time getting around your truck on a road with two or more lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Use the right lane.
questions.explanation: You should stay in the right lane of a multilane road if your vehicle is being slowed down by a heavy load. Allow other vehicles to pass your truck using the left lane.

questions.question: Texting while driving is especially dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is both a mental and physical distraction.
questions.answerB: A message may be upsetting to the driver.
questions.answerC: People like to read and may become too engaged in their phones.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is particularly dangerous because it is both a mental and physical distraction to the driver. In addition to diverting a driver's mental attention away from the road, texting requires a person to remove at least one hand from the vehicle's controls.

questions.question: What do the two systems of a dual air brake system share?
questions.answerB: An air compressor
questions.answerC: Air tanks
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: What is often found in compressed air?
questions.answerB: Cardboard
questions.answerC: Brake fluid
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle controls skills test exercise, your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: In the general area that was described by the examiner.
questions.answerB: In the exact final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerC: Within three feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pressed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop the vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerB: The truck is properly loaded.
questions.answerC: The cargo is mostly in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is essential to the safe operation of a CMV that cargo be properly loaded. Improper loading can affect handling and damage the vehicle. Additionally, improperly loaded materials can cause injury or death by falling off of the vehicle.

questions.question: What is axle weight?
questions.answerA: The weight transmitted to the ground by one axle
questions.answerB: The weight of one axle
questions.answerC: How much weight an axle can hold
questions.explanation: "Axle weight" refers to the weight transmitted to the ground by one axle or one set of axles.

questions.question: Eating while driving:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to maximize your time.
questions.answerB: Is encouraged during long trips.
questions.answerC: Is a distraction to the driver.
questions.explanation: Eating while driving can be a dangerous distraction to the driver both because it diverts their attention away from the task at hand and requires them to remove a hand from the steering wheel.

questions.question: When driving, your mirrors should:
questions.answerA: Not be used, as they are distracting.
questions.answerB: Not be used unless there is traffic.
questions.answerC: Be checked regularly.
questions.explanation: It is important for you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. To do this, regularly check your mirrors.

questions.question: How does doubling your speed from 20 mph to 40 mph affect your vehicle's braking distance?
questions.answerB: It doubles.
questions.answerC: It quadruples.
questions.explanation: Increasing your vehicle's speed will increase your vehicle's striking power and braking distance. Doubling your vehicle's speed from 20 to 40 mph will quadruple its braking distance.

questions.question: On slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerB: Adjust your driving to match weather conditions.
questions.answerC: Tailgate other vehicles.
questions.explanation: On a slippery road, you must adjust your driving speed to fit conditions. Because it will take longer for your vehicle to stop on a slippery road than on a dry road, you should increase your following distance when conditions are slippery. Avoid driving in a way that requires you to change speeds frequently.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.answerB: Pushing down quickly.
questions.answerC: Pulling up gradually.
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: Rolling backward when beginning to accelerate is dangerous because:
questions.answerB: The truck is not made to go backwards.
questions.answerC: You may hit a vehicle behind you.
questions.explanation: Be sure that you are able to accelerate without first rolling back. Rolling backwards may cause you to collide with a vehicle or other obstacle behind your truck.

questions.question: Before a bus enters a curve, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Not change their speed.
questions.answerC: Reduce their speed.
questions.explanation: Buses should always enter curves at reduced speeds. A driver should be especially cautious if entering a curve under wet or slippery conditions.

questions.question: When using a turn signal, you should not:
questions.answerB: Signal continuously.
questions.answerC: Allow the turn signal to stay on long after the turn has been completed.
questions.explanation: Always signal well ahead of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously until you have completed the turn or lane change, then be sure to cancel the signal so you do not confuse other drivers.

questions.question: Some water and compressor oil is usually found in the compressed air within an air brake system. The water and compressor oil:
questions.answerA: Are necessary for the proper function of the system.
questions.answerB: Should take up about 10 percent of the tank.
questions.answerC: Should be removed regularly.
questions.explanation: If water and compressor oil are left to build up in an air brake system, the system can be damaged. Air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow this accumulation to be removed. Manually controlled drains should be operated at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: What is the number one cause of death and injury in a work zone?
questions.answerB: Slow drivers
questions.answerC: Animals crossing the road
questions.explanation: Speeding is the leading cause of death and injury in work zones. Use extra caution when driving near workers in a work zone.

questions.question: One way to prevent drowsiness while driving is to:
questions.answerB: Avoid regular exercise.
questions.answerC: Get adequate sleep the night before the trip.
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness. Exercising regularly can increase your energy levels and make you less likely to become tired while driving.

questions.question: You should check and adjust your mirrors:
questions.answerB: While driving.
questions.answerC: After driving.
questions.explanation: Be sure to check your mirrors before beginning a drive. Your posture may change day to day and your mirrors may need to be adjusted.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/left parking maneuver, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: To transport hazardous materials, what does a driver need?
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement
questions.answerC: A CDL with a tank endorsement
questions.answerD: A CDL with a cargo endorsement
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used for transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be in the vehicle?
questions.answerB: Goggles
questions.answerC: An axe
questions.explanation: If transporting chlorine in cargo tanks, a driver must have an approved gas mask in their vehicle.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.answerC: Made of cardboard.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials should be braced so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle controls skills test exercise, your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: In the general area that was described by the examiner.
questions.answerB: In the exact final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerC: Within three feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: To complete a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest, you must:
questions.answerB: Only sign the manifest if you cross into another state.
questions.answerC: Have a witness sign the manifest.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting hazardous waste, you must carry with you a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. The manifest must be signed by hand.

questions.question: How often are hazardous materials employees required to be trained and tested?
questions.answerB: Once every three years
questions.answerC: Once every five years
questions.explanation: All drivers must be trained in the security risks of hazardous materials transportation. This training must include how to recognize and respond to possible security threats. Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Hop directly from their seat to the ground.
questions.answerB: Maintain at least one point of contact with their vehicle.
questions.answerC: Be turned to face their vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerC: Check traffic in all directions.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerB: The gas pedal is loose.
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, it is important to maintain ____ with your vehicle at all times.
questions.answerB: Four points of contact
questions.answerC: Two points of contact
questions.explanation: As you exit your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: You may leave a vehicle that is carrying explosives unattended:
questions.answerB: In a safe haven.
questions.answerC: On the shoulder of a highway.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: If you are transporting hazardous materials and the cargo catches on fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to put out the fire with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerB: Contact emergency personnel and let them battle the fire.
questions.answerC: Continue driving to the fire department.
questions.explanation: Fighting a hazardous materials fire requires specialized training and equipment. Unless you possess these yourself, it is best to let emergency personnel deal with the fire.

questions.question: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.answerB: The Federal Bureau of Investigation
questions.answerC: The Department of Energy
questions.explanation: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a federal security threat assessment done by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: Who must mark and label the materials for shipping?
questions.answerB: The shipper
questions.answerC: The driver
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for correctly labeling and marking them. The driver should make sure that the shipper properly labeled and marked the materials before beginning a trip.

questions.question: When completing a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.answerB: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: An encroachment is when:
questions.answerA: A driver does not appear for their scheduled basic skills test.
questions.answerB: A vehicle touches an exercise boundary line during the basic skills test.
questions.answerC: A driver fails one section of the basic skills test.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You may proceed across the tracks without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track, regardless of the presence of a train.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle may be:
questions.answerB: Either awake or asleep inside the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Within 100 feet of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A person attending a parked placarded vehicle must be either awake inside the vehicle or they must be within 100 feet of it. If not inside the vehicle itself, the person must have a clear view of the vehicle. The person attending may not be inside the sleeper berth.

questions.question: Unless excepted, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerB: The address of the shipper.
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: Unless excepted, hazardous materials shipping papers must list an emergency response telephone number.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually which shape?
questions.answerB: A triangle
questions.answerC: A diamond
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle can only be moved:
questions.answerA: To make room for other vehicles.
questions.answerB: In an emergency.
questions.answerC: If the vehicle will be traveling fewer than 10 miles.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that has not been properly placarded may not be driven, except when necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is shaped like a:
questions.answerB: Triangle.
questions.answerC: Circle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are diamond-shaped.

questions.question: A manifest for transporting hazardous waste:
questions.answerB: Must be sent electronically.
questions.answerC: Must be attached to the outside of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting hazardous waste, you must carry with you a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. The manifest must be signed by hand.

questions.question: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must carry a fire extinguisher with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: Shippers package in order to ____ hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Release
questions.answerC: Insulate
questions.explanation: Shippers package hazardous materials in a way that is meant to completely contain the materials. Vehicles should be placarded to communicate the risk of the cargo.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.answerC: General driving behavior.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you may park no closer than ____ from the nearest building.
questions.answerB: 50 feet
questions.answerC: 300 feet
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you should not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building, unless you are parking for a short period of time while performing an operational necessity, like refueling.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are usually shaped like:
questions.answerB: Triangles.
questions.answerC: Diamonds.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are usually diamond-shaped.

questions.question: When loading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use:
questions.answerB: Hooks.
questions.answerC: Straps.
questions.explanation: Always protect containers of hazardous materials. When loading hazardous materials, never use equipment that could damage containers or packaging, such as hooks.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time in order to place emphasis on different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time to prevent you from forgetting anything.
questions.answerC: Once in a while.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on shipping papers:
questions.answerA: An inhalation hazard placard must be used, but only if more than 100 pounds of the material are being transported.
questions.answerB: An inhalation hazard placard must be used when any amount of the material is being transported.
questions.answerC: Air masks must be provided to anyone handling the cargo.
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" are on a package or its shipping paper, you must display the proper inhalation hazard placards, as well as any other necessary placards. This applies regardless of the amount of materials being carried.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination.
questions.answerC: How much the material weighs.
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/left parking maneuver, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: The National Response Center must be notified of an incident resulting in any of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Injury requiring hospitalization.
questions.answerC: Injury not requiring hospitalization.
questions.explanation: The National Response Center must be notified of any incident that results in death; hospitalization; $50,000 or more in estimated property damage; an evacuation of the general public or closure of a major transportation route/facility for more then one hour; fire, breakage, spillage, or suspected contamination involving radiation, bacteria, or toxins. Additionally, if the carrier judges the situation to be so serious that it should be reported, it should be reported.

questions.question: If transporting hazardous materials, a shipper should warn others by:
questions.answerA: Posting HazMat placards on their truck.
questions.answerB: Putting flashing lights on their truck.
questions.answerC: Sounding a siren.
questions.explanation: Shippers of certain kinds of hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs, known as placards, on any transporting vehicles. Shippers are required to provide applicable placards, labels, shipping papers, and emergency response information.

questions.question: A placard identifying hazardous materials must be placed:
questions.answerB: Inside the cab.
questions.answerC: On the outside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When required, hazardous materials placards must be placed on the front, rear, and both sides of a vehicle.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, a look is when:
questions.answerA: A driver checks the gauges on their instrument panel.
questions.answerB: A driver checks their blind spots.
questions.answerC: A driver walks to the back of their vehicle to check its position.
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: If you're transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you should notify other drivers:
questions.answerB: With reflective triangles.
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down while you are transporting explosives and you need to use warning signals, use reflective triangles or red electric lights. Never use burning signals, such as flares or fuses, when transporting explosives.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is which shape?
questions.answerB: Triangle
questions.answerC: Circle
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: What does a shipping paper describe?
questions.answerB: How the materials will be transported
questions.answerC: Who should accept the materials being transported
questions.explanation: Among other information, shipping papers must include a description of the specific hazardous materials being transported.

questions.question: If you notice a cargo leak, you should identify the leaking hazardous materials by:
questions.answerB: Touching the materials.
questions.answerC: Using the shipping papers.
questions.explanation: If you discover a cargo leak while transporting hazardous materials, use the shipping papers, label, or package location to identify which materials are involved. Do not try to touch or smell the leaking materials to determine what they are because doing so could result in injury or death.

questions.question: ____ are used to warn others of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Flashing lights
questions.answerC: Color-coded pieces of tape
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs called placards are placed on bulk packages and on the outside of vehicles to warn drivers and others of the presence of hazardous materials. It is the responsibility of the shipper to place the placards, and it is the responsibility of the driver to verify that the correct placards have been placed.

questions.question: To complete a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest, you must:
questions.answerB: Only sign the manifest if you cross into another state.
questions.answerC: Have a witness sign the manifest.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting hazardous waste, you must carry with you a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. The manifest must be signed by hand.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerB: Parallel park.
questions.answerC: Drive straight into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must carry a fire extinguisher with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: Placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Within three inches of other markings.
questions.answerB: So words or numbers are read from left to right.
questions.answerC: Upside down.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be placed on a vehicle at least three inches away from any other markings and must positioned so that the words or numbers are level and read from left to right.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in a trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.answerB: Cleaned with water.
questions.answerC: Left to air dry without washing.
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to corrosive liquids must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.answerB: Greased.
questions.answerC: Opened.
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: If "Inhalation Hazard" appears on a shipping paper, the shipper should provide which placard?
questions.answerB: Poison Gas or Poison Inhalation Hazard
questions.answerC: Reportable Quantity
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper or package, you must display the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.answerB: Removed.
questions.answerC: Opened.
questions.explanation: On a compressed gas tank, liquid discharge valves must always be kept closed, except during loading and unloading.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.answerC: General driving behavior.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: If taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take the test again on a route that does include a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your on-road driving test route does not include a railroad crossing, you may be asked to explain and demonstrate the proper railroad crossing procedures to the examiner at a simulated location.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerC: Check traffic in all directions.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually which shape?
questions.answerB: A triangle
questions.answerC: A diamond
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: As a driver, which of the following is not your job at the scene of an accident?
questions.answerA: Keeping people away from the scene.
questions.answerB: Taking heroic measures to put the fire out.
questions.answerC: Communicating the danger of the hazardous materials to response personnel.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident while carrying hazardous materials, it is your responsibility as the driver to keep people away from the scene; limit the spread of material if you can safely do so; inform emergency response personnel of the dangers posed by the materials; and provide emergency personnel with the shipping papers and emergency response information. Unless you have protective equipment and the necessary training, do not try to fight hazardous materials fires yourself.

questions.question: ____ is responsible for properly labeling hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The loader
questions.answerC: The driver
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: When alley docking, you should first:
questions.answerA: Position your vehicle directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerB: Back up directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Stop parallel to the outer boundary of the alley.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: During the driving test, when asked to make a lane change:
questions.answerA: You should not be concerned with other motorists.
questions.answerB: You should use your turn signal and change lanes when safe.
questions.answerC: You should make the lane change as quickly as possible, even if that means cutting off another driver.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a lane change during the on-road driving test, you should make the proper traffic checks, use your turn signal, and smoothly change lanes when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Alcohol evaporators are:
questions.answerB: Used to add alcohol to braking systems to prevent items from freezing.
questions.answerC: Only allowed on vehicles carrying hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems include an alcohol evaporator. The evaporator introduces alcohol into the braking system to prevent the formation of ice, which can cause damage.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerB: The nuts are loose.
questions.answerC: The nuts are too tight.
questions.explanation: It is important to inspect your tires before every drive. Rust around wheel nuts may indicate that they are loose.

questions.question: If the emergency air line loses pressure:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve will close.
questions.answerC: The rear trailer will detach from the combination.
questions.explanation: The tractor protection valve keeps air in the trailer's braking system should the trailer break away or develop a leak. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the tractor protection valve to open and the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: If a vehicle's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is malfunctioning:
questions.answerA: The vehicle will have no brakes.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will still be able to brake.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will likely travel faster than usual.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) intervenes to reduce brake pressure if there is a risk of wheel lockup. If the ABS isn't working, the vehicle's basic braking functions are not affected. A driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal manner.

questions.question: If there is ice on the front of your side mirror:
questions.answerB: You can expect ice to be on the roadway.
questions.answerC: There will not be ice on the roadway.
questions.explanation: If your mirrors or wiper blades become icy while you are driving, you can expect the road surface to be icy as well.

questions.question: Alcohol can be removed from your system:
questions.answerB: By drinking coffee.
questions.answerC: By waiting.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate, so the only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to allow your body time to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to skid, it is best for the driver to:
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Quickly turn the steering wheel in one direction, then in the other.
questions.explanation: If your trailer begins to skid, you should release the brakes to regain traction. The trailer will begin to straighten out once the wheels begin to grip the road again.

questions.question: Rolling backward when beginning to accelerate is dangerous because:
questions.answerB: The truck is not made to go backwards.
questions.answerC: You may hit a vehicle behind you.
questions.explanation: Be sure that you are able to accelerate without first rolling back. Rolling backwards may cause you to collide with a vehicle or other obstacle behind your truck.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerB: Rise slowly.
questions.answerC: Hold steady.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the coolant temperature should begin a gradual rise toward the normal operating range.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make a visual check of a coupling to ensure that:
questions.answerA: There is a space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: The kingpin is free from all dirt and dust.
questions.answerC: The locking jaws are closed on the kingpin.
questions.explanation: When performing a visual check of coupling devices, you should make sure there is no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel. Ensure that the locking jaws are securely closed around the kingpin.

questions.question: If approaching a vehicle with a distracted driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Maintain a safe distance from the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Closely follow the vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you see a distracted driver, give them plenty of space and maintain a safe following distance.

questions.question: Slow down and be extra careful:
questions.answerB: When driving on dry pavement.
questions.answerC: When approaching a work zone.
questions.explanation: Slow down and be especially careful when driving in and around work zones, in places where the pavement drops off sharply at the edge of the road, when foreign objects are present on the road, and on freeway on- and off-ramps.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: When backing up while coupling a trailer, the tractor should be positioned:
questions.answerA: Directly in front of the trailer.
questions.answerB: Directly next to the trailer.
questions.answerC: Parallel with the trailer.
questions.explanation: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor directly in front of the trailer. Trying to couple while backing at an angle could cause the trailer to move and the landing gear to break.

questions.question: What is the Johnson bar?
questions.answerA: A hand valve that works the trailer brakes
questions.answerB: A valve that indicates the fuel level
questions.answerC: A valve that limits the amount of cargo
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes. Using it while a vehicle is in motion could cause a skid.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: When there is extra space on a truck.
questions.answerC: Only when the amount of hazardous materials on a truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.explanation: Warning placards are required to be used any time a vehicle is carrying designated types and amounts of hazardous materials. A placarded vehicle must display placards on all four of its sides.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.answerB: Use the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Downshift.
questions.explanation: You should always slow down to a safe speed and shift into a lower gear before entering a curve.

questions.question: Before driving a power steering-equipped vehicle, you should make sure that:
questions.answerA: The fluid is at a proper level.
questions.answerB: The hoses are connected to the battery.
questions.answerC: Any leak is small.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle that is equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should look for leaks in the hoses.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has started to skid is by:
questions.answerB: Checking the trailer in your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Feeling the trailer move.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to become aware that your trailer has begun to jackknife is to observe it in your mirrors. Checking your trailer in your mirrors will also allow you to spot any skidding at the earliest possible moment.

questions.question: If your wheels being to spin when accelerating on a poor traction surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Take your foot off the accelerator.
questions.answerC: Continue to accelerate.
questions.explanation: If your drive wheels begin to spin while accelerating on a surface with poor traction, you should remove your foot from the accelerator.

questions.question: A cracked rim should be:
questions.answerB: Relocated to one of a pair of dual tires.
questions.answerC: Replaced.
questions.explanation: A driver should inspect wheels before a drive, specifically looking for damage on the wheels and rims. Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use.

questions.question: If there is a cargo fire in a box trailer:
questions.answerA: The trailer doors should be opened.
questions.answerB: The trailer doors should not be opened.
questions.answerC: A large, heavy blanket should be put over the trailer.
questions.explanation: The doors of a trailer should be not be opened in the event of a cargo fire, especially if the cargo includes hazardous materials. Opening trailer doors would increase the fire's oxygen supply, potentially causing the fire to increase in size.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired and yawning a lot while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and take a nap.
questions.answerB: Get some coffee.
questions.answerC: Drive faster.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel tired while driving, you should stop to get some sleep. Trying to push on to reach your destination while tired is dangerous. You should not rely on caffeine to keep you awake.

questions.question: When trying to put out an electrical fire, you should:
questions.answerB: Use a B:C extinguisher.
questions.answerC: Use an X extinguisher.
questions.explanation: B:C fire extinguishers are designed to work on electrical fires and burning liquids. Don't pour water on an electrical fire.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS):
questions.answerB: Are only used on tucks carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Allow drivers to stay in control when braking.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheels from locking up during a hard application of brakes.

questions.question: Always perform the steps of a pre-trip inspection in the same order each time because:
questions.answerA: You will be less likely to forget something.
questions.answerB: You will have more time to complete the inspection.
questions.answerC: It is required by law.
questions.explanation: Completing the steps of a vehicle inspection in the same order before every trip aids in learning what the proper steps are. Additionally, you be less likely to forget a step when going through the checklist in a prescribed order.

questions.question: To help prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Placed as high as possible inside a trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed as low as possible inside a trailer.
questions.answerC: Placed on the driver’s side of a trailer.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is top-heavy, it is more likely to roll over. The weight of cargo should be positioned as low in a trailer as possible to minimize this risk.

questions.question: After an accident, flares should be used with caution because:
questions.answerA: There may be fuel spilled on the ground that could catch fire.
questions.answerB: Other drivers may not see the flares if the weather is sunny.
questions.answerC: Flares are expensive.
questions.explanation: A common cause of vehicle fires in the aftermath of an accident is the improper use of flares near spilled fuel. Use flares with caution.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked vehicles, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Watch for signs of a person exiting a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Flash their headlights.
questions.explanation: You should be cautious when passing parked vehicles. A person may step out of a parked vehicle or out from between parked vehicles without looking for oncoming traffic. A driver may begin moving their vehicle before realizing you are there.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerA: Are not a cause for concern.
questions.answerB: Are extremely dangerous.
questions.answerC: Cannot be identified.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up a vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in this system are extremely dangerous.

questions.question: If you are braking on dry pavement while traveling at 55 mph, how much distance will brake lag add to your overall stopping distance?
questions.answerB: 45 feet
questions.answerC: 20 feet
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to the vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road:
questions.answerA: A driver should keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.answerB: A driver should turn on the emergency flashers.
questions.answerC: The driver should wave their arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, make sure to use your four-way emergency flashers. This is particularly important at night.

questions.question: Which of the following is an indication of standing water on the roadway?
questions.answerB: Portions of the pavement that are dry
questions.answerC: Leaves on the road
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning can occur in places where water collects on the road. Clear reflections, tire splashes, or rain drops on the road can indicate the presence of standing water.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely pass under an upcoming bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve while under the bridge.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: If you aren't sure that you have room for your vehicle to safely fit under an overhead object, you should slow down while approaching it. Seek an alternate route, if possible.

questions.question: When driving, knowing what is happening behind you is:
questions.answerB: Important.
questions.answerC: Distracting.
questions.explanation: To travel safely, it is essential that you know what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Use your mirrors frequently to help you remain aware of your surroundings.

questions.question: Why are multi-speed axles and auxiliary transmissions used?
questions.answerA: To make a vehicle operate more smoothly
questions.answerB: To provide extra gears
questions.answerC: To improve a vehicle's gas mileage
questions.explanation: On many vehicles, multi-speed rear axles and auxiliary transmissions are used to provide extra gears.

questions.question: Most heavy vehicles use the ____ method when changing gears.
questions.answerB: Double shifting
questions.answerC: Triple clutching
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with unsynchronized manual transmissions require double clutching to change gears.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerA: Are not safe to be used.
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires on the rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used only when carrying a heavy load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs should never be used.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: It is best not to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive under foggy conditions, be sure to decrease your speed.

questions.question: When you are pulling a trailer, the air supply control lever should be in its ____ position.
questions.answerB: Supply
questions.answerC: Normal
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerB: Tires are not made to drive in wet weather.
questions.answerC: The water yet hasn't absorbed the dirt and grease.
questions.explanation: Roads are often especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Rainwater forms a slick film when mixed with oil and grease on the road surface that has not yet washed away.

questions.question: You may leave a vehicle that is carrying explosives unattended:
questions.answerB: In a safe haven.
questions.answerC: On the shoulder of a highway.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: If you remain in neutral for too long while switching gears:
questions.answerB: You may have trouble putting the vehicle into the next gear.
questions.answerC: You may kill the engine.
questions.explanation: If you remain in neutral for too long while switching gears, you may have difficulty putting the vehicle into the next gear. If this happens, do not try to force the gear shift. Instead, return to neutral, release the clutch, increase the engine speed to match the road speed, and try again.

questions.question: To transport hazardous materials, what does a driver need?
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement
questions.answerC: A CDL with a tank endorsement
questions.answerD: A CDL with a cargo endorsement
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used for transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: Regrooved tires:
questions.answerA: Should not be used on any vehicle.
questions.answerB: Should not be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: Should not be used on trucks hauling gravel.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: When backing up while coupling a trailer, the tractor should be positioned:
questions.answerA: Directly in front of the trailer.
questions.answerB: Directly next to the trailer.
questions.answerC: Parallel with the trailer.
questions.explanation: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor directly in front of the trailer. Trying to couple while backing at an angle could cause the trailer to move and the landing gear to break.

questions.question: The safety belt should:
questions.answerB: Latch securely.
questions.answerC: Be frayed.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should verify that the safety belt is securely mounted, adjusts, latches properly, and is not ripped or frayed.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no more than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement.
questions.explanation: Cargo inside a trailer must be secured appropriately to prevent it from shifting in transit.

questions.question: On any upgrade, gravity will:
questions.answerB: Slow your vehicle down.
questions.answerC: Not impact your speed.
questions.explanation: A vehicle will be slowed down by gravity on any uphill grade. You may need to switch to a lower gear to climb a steep grade.

questions.question: On a curve, the posted speed limit:
questions.answerA: Is safe to be driven in any vehicle.
questions.answerB: Can still permit a vehicle to tip over.
questions.answerC: Is understood to be the minimum legal speed limit.
questions.explanation: The posted speed limit on a curve may be safe to be taken by cars, but can still be too fast to be taken by larger vehicles, such as trucks. An operator driving their truck at the posted limit on a curve could cause their vehicle to tip over.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Can be avoided by eating while driving.
questions.answerB: Can be increased by pre-programming radio stations.
questions.answerC: Can be avoided by not engaging in complex conversations with others.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: If you are confronted with an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to stay in their way.
questions.answerC: Ignore any hand gestures.
questions.explanation: The best thing to do when confronted with an aggressive driver is to get out of their way, if possible. Avoid making eye contact, which could further provoke the driver. Ignore any hand gestures made by the driver.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel:
questions.answerA: In the direction you want the trailer to move.
questions.answerB: In the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to move.
questions.answerC: To the left until backing is complete.
questions.explanation: When backing a vehicle with a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once your trailer starts to turn, you should turn the steering wheel the other way to follow the trailer.

questions.question: The National Response Center must be notified of an incident resulting in any of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Injury requiring hospitalization.
questions.answerC: Injury not requiring hospitalization.
questions.explanation: The National Response Center must be notified of any incident that results in death; hospitalization; $50,000 or more in estimated property damage; an evacuation of the general public or closure of a major transportation route/facility for more then one hour; fire, breakage, spillage, or suspected contamination involving radiation, bacteria, or toxins. Additionally, if the carrier judges the situation to be so serious that it should be reported, it should be reported.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driver’s side is encouraged:
questions.answerA: Because it allows the driver a better view.
questions.answerB: Because turning toward the passenger side is illegal.
questions.answerC: Because other drivers can offer assistance.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best advice for driving in fog?
questions.answerA: Try not to drive in fog.
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Turn off your lights.
questions.explanation: Driving in fog is always dangerous and should be avoided entirely if at all possible. If you must drive in fog, be sure to turn on your low beam headlights and fog lights, even during the daytime.

questions.question: The emergency air line supplies air to the:
questions.answerB: Trailer air tanks.
questions.answerC: Signal line.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks, and the second is to control the emergency brakes on combination vehicles.

questions.question: A tread depth of ____ should be in every major groove of a front tire.
questions.answerB: 2/32 of an inch
questions.answerC: 4/32 of an inch
questions.explanation: For safe operation, a commercial motor vehicle needs a tread depth of 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and a tread depth of 2/32 of an inch on other tires.

questions.question: ____ is responsible for properly labeling hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The loader
questions.answerC: The driver
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Get upset.
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downgrade.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure  from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place. Instead, use the parking brake or wheel chocks.

questions.question: You will often have to drive your vehicle under bridges and overpasses. If approaching such an opening, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the posted clearance height is accurate.
questions.answerB: Assume the posted clearance height is inaccurate.
questions.answerC: Measure the height of the opening before proceeding.
questions.explanation: Do not assume that posted height clearances are accurate. If the road was repaved after the sign was posted, or if there is packed snow on the ground, the actual height of the opening may be different than what is indicated. If you are not confident that your vehicle will be able to safely clear an upcoming bridge or overpass, you should slow down and find another path, if possible.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.answerB: Away from heat sources.
questions.answerC: Away from shadows.
questions.explanation: Always load hazardous materials away from heat sources. Be aware of regulations on explosive or flammable materials that prohibit them from being loaded in cargo spaces with heaters.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerB: 1/8 of a second
questions.answerC: 3/4 of a second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time between three-quarters of a second and one second. At 55 mph, this corresponds to a distance of 61 feet traveled.

questions.question: How much water must be present for a vehicle to hydroplane?
questions.answerB: A good amount, such as a large puddle
questions.answerC: A small amount
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be much water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: In hot weather, spots on the pavement where tar is bleeding:
questions.answerB: Offer the same amount of traction as the rest of the roadway.
questions.answerC: Offer more traction than the rest of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Tar in road pavement often rises to the surface of the road, or "bleeds," in very hot weather. Watch for such areas because they can be very slippery.

questions.question: Heights posted at bridges:
questions.answerB: Are legally binding.
questions.answerC: Can be incorrect.
questions.explanation: Never assume that the posted height on a bridge or other overhead object is correct. Even if it was accurate when posted, things may have changed that affect clearance, either permanently (such as a repaving of the road) or temporarily (such as packed snow on the road).

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerB: Usually happens when vehicles are traveling faster than 65 mph.
questions.answerC: Can occur with a minimal amount of water on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be a large amount of water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: What eliminates alcohol from the bloodstream?
questions.answerB: Exercise
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: The body processes alcohol at a fixed rate that cannot be sped up through tricks like drinking coffee. The only way to sober up is to give the body the time it needs to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Can cause mechanical damage.
questions.answerC: Is required on slippery surfaces.
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When backing up your tractor while coupling it to a trailer, the trailer brakes should be:
questions.answerB: Locked.
questions.answerC: Unlocked.
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. Before backing your tractor under the trailer while coupling, make sure your trailer brakes are locked.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driver’s side is encouraged because:
questions.answerA: The driver will have the best possible view.
questions.answerB: Power lines should be on the passenger's side.
questions.answerC: Other drivers can offer assistance on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: When driving in reverse, it is always recommended that a driver backs their vehicle toward its left side. This will allow the driver the best possible view of the rear of their vehicle.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: The loader
questions.answerC: The driver
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply the warning placards.

questions.question: How can a driver maintain alertness while driving?
questions.answerB: Keep the cab warm
questions.answerC: Eat heavy foods
